'''Bob Stroger''' (born 1939) is an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] bass guitarist, singer and songwriter.  He has worked with many blues musicians including [[Eddie King (musician)|Eddie King]], [[Otis Rush]], [[Jimmy Rogers]], [[Eddie Taylor]], [[Eddy Clearwater]], [[Sunnyland Slim]], [[Louisiana Red]], [[Buster Benton]], [[Homesick James]], [[Mississippi Heat]], [[Snooky Pryor]], [[Odie Payne]], [[Fred Below]], [[Willie "Big Eyes" Smith]], and [[Billy Davenport]].<ref name="AMG"/>

In 2011 and 2013, Stroger was granted a [[Blues Music Award]] as Best Blues Bassist.

==Life and career==
Stroger was born on a farm outside of [[Hayti, Missouri]], United States,<ref name="Bob">{{cite web|url=http://www.corbydesigns.com/bobstroger/bio.htm |title=Bob Stroger Website |publisher=Corbydesigns.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-07}}</ref> and in 1955 when aged 16, he relocated with his family to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]].<ref name="Today">{{cite book
| first= Karen
| last= Hanson
| year= 2007
| title= Today's Chicago Blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Lake Claremont Press 
| location= [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]
| isbn= 1-893121-19-4
| pages= 196/8}}</ref> His family settled in an apartment on the West Side in an apartment in the back of Silvio's [[nightclub]].  Stroger was inspired by the sights and sounds emanating from the club.  Subsequently he was further encouraged to try to have a career in music, after being casually employed driving his brother-in-law to play in a blues band alongside [[J. B. Hutto]].<ref name="Today"/>  Self-taught in the art of guitar playing, Stroger got together a family based band known as the Red Tops, named after wearing black berets with a red circle daubed on top. When [[Willie Kent]] was drafted to boost their proficiency, the combo was renamed Joe Russell and the Blues Hustlers. Stroger had adopted the [[stage name]] of Joe Russell, although this did not endure.<ref name="AMG"/> He moved on to play [[jazz]] for a period with Rufus Forman, but it was his meeting with [[Eddie King (musician)|Eddie King]] which started his lengthy career playing blues.  Having now adopted playing bass guitar, Stroger played on King's [[Single (music)|single]] "Love You Baby" (1965).<ref name="Today"/>

He backed King for fifteen years before King relocated, which caused Stroger to stop his playing for a couple of years.<ref name="AMG"/>  His interest was rekindled when he was recommended to [[Otis Rush]], whom he backed in the late 1970s and 1980s.<ref name="airwayrecords1">{{cite web|url=http://airwayrecords.com/bob-is-back-in-town/ |title=Bob is Back in Town « Airway Records |publisher=Airwayrecords.com |date=1907-09-05 |accessdate=2013-03-07}}</ref> He toured Europe with Rush and played on a couple of his albums, ''Live in Europe'' and ''Lost in the Blues''.<ref name="Today"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/lost-in-the-blues-mw0000263196/credits |title=Lost in the Blues - Otis Rush : Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-07}}</ref>

Stroger became a [[session musician]] for a while, and worked with [[Sunnyland Slim]]<ref name="Today"/> and [[Mississippi Heat]] during the late 1980s and early 1990s, before joining [[Odie Payne]] as the regular rhythm section for the series of American Blues Folk Festivals.<ref name="AMG"/> Encouraged by Sunnyland Slim, Stroger began singing and writing his own material.<ref name="airwayrecords1"/> In 1996, Stroger played on [[Mark Hummel]]'s album, ''Heart of Chicago''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/heart-of-chicago-mw0000091236/credits |title=Heart of Chicago - Mark Hummel : Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date=1997-01-14 |accessdate=2013-03-07}}</ref> In 1997, Stroger played bass on [[Golden "Big" Wheeler]]'s album, ''Jump In''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/jump-in-mw0000597358/credits |title=Jump In - Big Wheeler : Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-07}}</ref> The following year, Stroger played with a group of musicians at the Lucerne Blues Festival in Switzerland.  This led to the recording of his debut solo album, ''In the House: Live at Lucerne, Vol. 1'', where he was accompanied by [[Ken Saydak]] and [[Billy Flynn (musician)|Billy Flynn]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crosscut.de/index.php?article_id=59&clang=1 |title=CrossCut Records | Bob Stroger & His Chicago Blues Legends featuring the Ken Saydak Trio: In The House - Live at Lucerne Vol.1 |publisher=Crosscut.de |date= |accessdate=2013-03-07}}</ref>  

In 2007, Stroger recorded ''Bob Is Back in Town'' in Chicago, backed by [[Steve Freund]] (guitar), [[Willie "Big Eyes" Smith]] (harmonica), [[Deitra Farr]] (backing vocals), and [[Juli Wood]] (baritone saxophone).<ref name="airwayrecords1"/> The same year he backed [[Carey Bell]] on his final recorded work, ''Gettin Up: Live at Buddy Guy's Legends Rosa's'' ([[Delmark Records|Delmark]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/gettin-up-live-at-buddy-guys-legends-rosas-mw0000489121/credits |title=Gettin' Up: Live at Buddy Guy's Legends Rosa's - Carey Bell : Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date=2007-04-17 |accessdate=2013-03-07}}</ref> He also played on Willie "Big Eyes" Smith's, ''Born in Arkansas'' (2008) and ''Joined at the Hip'' (with [[Pinetop Perkins]]) (2010).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/joined-at-the-hip-mw0001989737/credits |title=Joined at the Hip - Pinetop Perkins, Willie "Big Eyes" Smith : Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date=2010-06-08 |accessdate=2013-03-07}}</ref>

In 2011, the [[Blues Foundation]] presented Stroger with a [[Blues Music Award]] in the Best Blues Bassist category.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.deltabohemian.com/blues-music-awards-2011-delta-bohemian-perspective/ |title=Blues Music Awards 2011 - A Delta Bohemian Perspective |publisher=Deltabohemian.com |date=2011-05-26 |accessdate=2013-03-07}}</ref> He was nominated in the same category in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blues.org/#ref=bluesmusicawards_nominees|title=Blues Music Awards Nominees - 2013 - 34th Blues Music Awards|publisher=Blues.org|accessdate=2013-03-21}}</ref>  He took home the Best Bassist Award again in 2013.
